conclusion: Velocity-time graph shows velocity as a function of time; area under graph gives displacement.
Displacement is found by integrating velocity over time; difference in displacement is area under A minus area under B.
Velocity of both objects is positive, increases initially, reaches maximum, then decreases to zero at t1.
Area under curve for A is total area under curve for A up to t1.
Area under curve for B is total area under curve for B up to t1.
Difference in displacement is area under A minus area under B; area under A is always above area under B until t1.
Intersection point indicates time when displacements are equal; after this, area under A decreases relative to B, causing difference in displacement to decrease.
Difference in displacement is not necessarily continuously increasing; it increases until curves intersect, then decreases.
Final answer is No, difference in displacement is not necessarily continuously increasing.
